Their coloration is generally pale or grayish, with some darker markings or patterns on the wings and body.

These mayflies are found in freshwater habitats, such as rivers, streams, and lakes, throughout North America. They play an important role in aquatic food webs, serving as prey for various predators, including fish, birds, and other invertebrates. Their presence is often used as an indicator of water quality, as they are sensitive to environmental changes and pollution.

The life cycle of Neocloeon triangulifer follows the typical mayfly pattern, with aquatic nymphal stages and a brief adult stage focused on reproduction before they die. The nymphs undergo a series of molts as they grow and develop, eventually emerging as winged adults to mate and continue the cycle.
